newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: PM says no racism debate raging in Australia. [CORRECTED 05:50 GMT]
newsitem.headline: PM says no racism debate raging in Australia. [CORRECTED 05:50 GMT]

text.p: Prime Minister John Howard on Monday denied that anti-Asian remarks by a maverick politician had set off a "raging" national debate on racism and said Australians should be proud of their history of immigration.
Howard, who has resisted pressure to openly condemn independent member of parliament Pauline Hanson for her views, accused the media of inflaming the whole racism issue.
"I think the claims that have been made by many people in recent days about a racism debate in the Australian community are superficial and juvenile," Howard told state radio.
"I don't think there's a raging racist debate in the Australian community at all."
Howard was commenting on a newspaper interview on Sunday in which Hanson warned that Australia faced a Bosnia-style civil war if migrants and Aborigines continued to get special treatment.
(Corrects to make clear warning came in an interview, not a speech)
Hanson, a fish and chip shop owner from conservative Queensland state, has dominated Australian headlines since her maiden parliamentary speech last month.
She used that speech to criticise the government over the number of Asians in the country, warned of an Asian invasion threat, and even took a swipe at indigenous Aborgines.
An opinion poll in The Sydney Morning Herald newspaper last week found 48 percent of respondents backed Hanson, while only 38 percent disagreed with her views.

Australian agricultural and trade officials have expressed concern that the row could harm the country's burgeoning trade ties with its neighbours in Asia. Asians make up around one-third of the 100,000 immigrants into Australia every year.
But Howard said on Monday he believed the majority of Australians were not racist.

"Most Australians are very tolerant," he said. "... in reality, the great majority of Australians have demonstrated a capacity to absorb people from all around the world the like of which few other countries have achieved since the end of World War Two.
"That should be a source of pride -- it should not be a source of defensiveness."
Aware of the poll findings and with a parliamentary by-election due next weekend, both government and opposition have been stepping gingerly around Hanson and the racism row.
But opposition leader Kim Beazley, who has been increasingly critical of the MP, said on Monday she was an "unguided missile" that had to be shot back at.
"She's come out and said that we've got some equivalent Bosnian situation developing here and that is a load of cobblers (nonsense)," Beazley said in a radio interview.

"I think that what we've got here is a pretty unguided missile launched into the Australian community and we are just going to have, to every now and then, pepper it with a bit of counter-battery fire."
